descriptions.content:
Description

Literally "methods of accomplishment," these are ritual methods for attaining a religious goal, either for attaining mundane powers, or for attaining the state of a deity. Most often these take the form of a scripted liturgy that a practitioner recites while performing visualizations.

Note that sādhanas are occasionally refered to with the term las byang. For example, las byang can be used as an abbreviation for phrin las kyi byang bu ("manual for accomplishing the activities of the deity"). Sometimes (and generically) las byang is also used to refer to a collection of texts on a given deity (rta mgrin gyi las byang); in other instances las byang means any ritual action whatsoever (bya ba byed pa'i cho ga), and is therefore coterminous with the category of ritual itself. It is also used with the sense of sgom bzlas, though all these terms can also have other, broader meanings.

Related Terms

bdag bskyed, bdun bskyed, bsnyen thabs, bsnyen yig, bsnyen sgrub.

Secondary Sources

Bianchi, Esther. "Sādhana Della Divinità Solitaria Yamāntaka-Vajrabhairava: Traduzione E Glossario Della Version Cinese Di Nenghai (Parte Ii)." Revue d'Études Tibetaines 10 (2006): 4-43.

Cozort, Daniel. "Sādhana (Sgrub Thabs): Means of Achievement for Deity Yoga." In Tibetan Literature: Studies in Genre, edited by José Ignacio Cabezón and Roger Jackson, 331-343. Ithaca: Snow Lion Publications, 1996.
